p: The family Chloranthaceae includes plants grouped in four genera: Sarcandra Gardner, Chloranthus Sw., Ascarina J.R. Forst. and G. Forst., and Hedyosmum Sw. The genus Hedyosmum comprises 40 species of shrubs and small trees distributed from Mexico, throughout Central America to Bolivia, east of the Guianas and the Antilles [ 1]. The name Hedyosmum comes from the Greek “pleasant fragrance” and alludes to one of the most remarkable characteristics of these plants, the pleasant aromatic smell coming from all its parts [ 1, 2]. According to Todzia [ 1], different Hedyosmum species have been popularly used all around Central and South America for different purposes: H. scabrum (Ruiz & Pav.) Solms for conception stimulation; H. scabrum and H. scaberrimun Standl. as stomach pain relievers; H. sprucei Solms for snake bites; H. cumbalense H. Karst. as a stimulant; and H. racemosum (Ruiz & Pav.) G. Don as a treatment to joint pain. The essential oil composition from some species of this genus ( H. sprucei, H. arborescens Sw., H. scabrum, H. colombianum Cuatrec., H. angustifolium (Ruiz & Pav.) Solms, H. mexicanum C. Cordem., H. bonplandianum Mart., and H. costaricense C.E. Wood ex W.C. Burger) have previously been described [ 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8], as well as their antioxidant and cytotoxic properties [ 3, 4].
